item.title: Forgetting is a Feature
item.description:
If our brains could remember everything then nothing would be important. Our brains would be an even more calamitous place than it already is. The fact that we forget things we don’t use regularly is actually a feature to make room for the new things you will learn. It is like optimizing for Signal to Noise Ratio

References

item.title: In writing, what the author mean't is irrelevant
item.description:
This is an especially challenging trap for me as someone who doesn’t find writing easy. I often find myself in a scenario where someone reads (usually my wife) something I wrote and we discuss it, only for me to find out what I meant and what I wrote were not the same.

References

It is public because in the discussion, it does not matter anymore what the author meant, only what is there in writing. How to Take Smart Notes

item.title: The importance of Primary Actions
item.description:
“Use constraints so that the user feels as if there is only one possible thing to do — the right thing, of course.” Constraints work by reducing alternatives for users. A well-constructed system will present users as few alternatives as possible at each step.

References

7 Principles From “The Design of Everyday Things” by UI Blogger Feb, 2022 UX Planet

item.title: Increasing your "luck"
People with repeated success increase their chances of success by taking more shots
item.description:
Luck Successful People People with repeat success Increasing your visibility

This has the net effect of: Increasing your “luck”

Things to do:

  • Put stuff out into the world
  • Take more action
  • Do more things
  • Meet more people
  • Go to more events
  • Blog about your startup
  • Produce things & publish them
  • Get Feedback

References

from Ali Abdaal

item.title: Key Reasons People Play Video Games
item.description:
1. They are a temporary escape
  2. They are social
  3. They are a challenge
  4. They demonstrate constant measurable growth

References

Escaping video game addiction Cam Adair at TEDxBoulder

item.title: If you are struggling with Video Game Addiction, look for ways to get what you are getting out of those video games through other sources
item.description:
For me, it was about finding another challenge and a way to see constant measurable growth. A key thing that kept me from breaking the addiction earlier was the social time I got gaming with my cousin. He and I would play almost every night and that was a major portion of my social interaction. If I was going to stop gaming into the early morning hours each night, I would need to find additional ways to get that social interaction.

I decided to start digital gardening and producing a YouTube channel instead. I still game, but limit it to one or two nights a week.

Key Reasons People Play Video Games

References

Escaping video game addiction Cam Adair at TEDxBoulder

item.title: Read before bed to get better sleep
item.description:
Principles Reading Sleep

Days are busy and it is often difficult to carve out time to read during the pace of a typical day, but all days end in the bed and getting sleep. For me reading puts me to sleep so reading prior to sleep is a win-win for me.

It helps my brain explore, but also slow down and often leads to a handful of ideas before relaxing and going to sleep. I can normally tell that I’m ready to sleep when I begin reading the same line multiple times or can’t retain what I read.

If you’re going to be staying up late I can’t think of many things as productive as reading.

I also find that the quality of my sleep is better. Reading calms me and puts my mind and body into a state that makes it easier to transition into sleep. Reading before bed (at least non-fiction) is almost like Pre-sleep.

When I was younger I had a routine of masturbating before bed to help go to sleep, but looking back now I think this created some form of hormone that caused me to get worse sleep. It’s not that I didn’t fall asleep easily (I did), but I don’t feel that I was as well rested in the morning.

Don't Start from Scratch
item.description:
Starting from scratch is hard. Especially for me. The real value of PKM for me is having a foundation where I don’t have to start from scratch. An outline is basically already written and just needs to be assembled.

Building a foundation

item.title: Have a clear process for how you separate the end of the workday and the rest of your life
item.description:
Work Life Balance

  • Check your emails for any last urgent items.
  • Check for any Product Reviews
  • Is the Task Inbox processed?
  • Update your todo list of unfinished items.
  • Make sure every item in your todo list is scheduled to be done at some point.
  • Look through your calendar to make sure there aren’t important deadlines you forgot.
  • Make a todo list of tasks tomorrow.
  • Say “shutdown complete” to explicitly mark the end of work.

References

item.title: Avoid a second cup of coffee for better sleep
item.description:
Sleep Afternoon Coffee / Afternoon Tea

Second cup of coffee is wrecking my sleep tonight. I think it is a combination of nerves, caffeine and lack of exercise. I should promise myself to not have a 2nd cup of coffee without exercise, and ideally no 2nd coffee at all. Perhaps I can fit in a workout after the chat with Jacques. I need it.

Alternatives

  • Drink a Decaffinated Coffee similar in flavor to the one you normally drink. I drink Starbucks Espresso roast, and they make a decaffeinated version. It’s not quite as bold, but it gives a similar feel
  • Drink tea instead for a similar warm sensation

References

item.title: Think with paper and store conclusions digitally
item.description:
Think with paper and store conclusions digitally

Creative Thought url: https://decoding.io/2021/05/think-with-paper-and-store-conclusions-digitally/

  • There is quite a big difference between paper and digital tools, but they can complement each other nicely.
    • You can use paper to get an order in random ideas by doing doodles, wireframes, mindmaps, diagrams, or what have you. Because of its tactile feel and freeform nature, paper is a better tool for organizing your thoughts.
    • Digital tools make information easier to search, so they are great to store the results of your thinking that you unraveled using paper.
      • Unlike paper, digital tools are rigid, so they are not the most optimal way to support thinking.

item.title: Have capture tools everywhere
item.description:
Creative Thought

Stumbled upon https://decoding.io/2021/05/refactoring-my-gtd-system-part-2-the-capture-wallet/ today and it led me down the path of:

Have Capture Tools everywhere.

I’ve found on a number of occasions I have a good idea or at least something that keeps me from sleeping and being able to get it out of my head and on to paper would be preferred.

According to David Allen you can’t keep more than 4 things in your head without diminishing your cognitive ability. You mind is deceptive and you think you will remember, but you won’t. There is now a notebook by the bedside. I just need to put a few in the vehicles and I hopefully should be set.

Came across this: https://capturewallet.com/. Too expensive, but interesting.

  • Run to Barnes & Noble and see if they have a better Moleskine for on the go.

Notetaking
